purpose.summary: Establish consistent retention requirements for compensation-related documents and data to ensure compliance with legal and regulatory requirements, audit readiness and supportability, appropriate data destruction, and balance between retention needs and cost/risk management.
objectives: Ensure compliance with legal and regulatory requirements
Balance retention needs with cost and risk management

definitions.definition: Storage for current plus 3 years of data in primary systems (ICMT, HRIS, Finance/ERP, Email) readily accessible by authorized users.
Storage for years 4-7 in secure archive server, cloud archive, or offline backup media, retrievable within 5 business days upon request.

Exception to normal destruction schedule when litigation, investigation, or audit is pending or reasonably anticipated, requiring immediate suspension of all destruction of potentially relevant records.
A permanent log maintaining date of destruction, description of records destroyed, retention period applied, authorization, method of destruction, and certificate of destruction.

provisions.title: Retention Schedule
provisions.content: All compensation-related records must be retained according to the defined schedule, with 7 years as the standard retention period.

subProvisions.title: Plan Design Documentation
subProvisions.content: Retention requirements for plan design documents:
items: Plan documents (approved versions): 7 years after plan ends - Governance repository
Plan design models and analysis: 7 years after plan ends - Shared drive
Market benchmark data: 3 years - Comp team files
Approval records (CRB minutes, etc.): 7 years - Secure archive

subProvisions.title: Participant Data
items: Eligibility records: 7 years after termination - HRIS + ICMT
Quota assignments: 7 years - ICMT
Performance data: 7 years - ICMT + Data warehouse
Payout calculations: 7 years after payment - ICMT
Payment records: 7 years after payment - Finance systems
Participant statements: 7 years after issuance - ICMT / Archive

subProvisions.title: Financial Records
items: Accrual calculations: 7 years - Finance systems
GL reconciliations: 7 years - Finance systems
Budget vs. actual reports: 7 years - Finance systems
Tax withholding records: 7 years minimum - Payroll/Finance
W-2 copies: Permanent - HR/Payroll

subProvisions.title: System and Audit Documentation
subProvisions.content: Retention requirements for system and audit documentation:
items: System configuration history: 7 years - ICMT / IT
Audit reports (internal/external): 7 years - Governance archive
Control testing documentation: 7 years - Finance / Audit files
Data validation logs: 3 years - ICMT logs

subProvisions.title: Communications
items: Plan rollout communications: 7 years - Governance repository
Participant acknowledgments: 7 years after termination - ICMT / HR
Email re: plan interpretation: 3 years - Email archive
Training materials: Current version + 3 years - Training repository

subProvisions.title: Disputes and Exceptions
subProvisions.content: Retention requirements for dispute and exception records:
items: Dispute records: 7 years after resolution - ICMT / Legal files
Exception requests and approvals: 7 years - ICMT / Governance files
Investigation files: 7 years after close - HR / Legal files

provisions.title: Legal and Regulatory Basis
provisions.content: Retention periods are based on key legal and regulatory requirements. A conservative approach of 7 years standard is used to cover all requirements.

subProvisions.title: Key Requirements
items: IRS: Minimum 3 years (typically 7 years for caution)
SOX: Audit documentation for 7 years
State Wage Laws: Vary by state (3-7 years)
FLSA: 3 years (certain records)
EEOC: 1 year (employment records)
Securities Laws: 6-7 years (if applicable)

subProvisions.title: Legal Hold
subProvisions.content: If litigation, investigation, or audit is pending or reasonably anticipated:
items: STOP all destruction of potentially relevant records
Implement legal hold procedures
Consult Legal before any deletion
Maintain records until legal hold is lifted

provisions.title: Retention Period Calculation
provisions.content: Retention period start dates depend on the type of record.

subProvisions.title: Start Date
items: Plan documents: End date of plan year
Participant data: Termination date or last payment date, whichever is later
Payments: Date of payment
Disputes: Date of resolution
Financial records: End of fiscal year
Audits: Date of audit report

provisions.title: Storage Requirements
provisions.content: Data must be stored according to its age and access requirements.

subProvisions.title: Active Storage (Current + 3 Years)
subProvisions.content: Readily accessible by authorized users in primary systems:
items: ICMT (primary compensation system)
HRIS
Finance/ERP systems
Email systems

subProvisions.title: Archive Storage (Years 4-7)
subProvisions.content: Retrievable within 5 business days upon request, encrypted and access-controlled:
items: Secure archive server
Cloud archive (if approved)
Offline backup media

subProvisions.title: Paper Records
subProvisions.content: Paper may be scanned and destroyed after verification if scanning meets quality standards, electronic copy is legally equivalent, index allows easy retrieval, and approved by Legal.
items: Current: On-site secure storage
Archive: Off-site secure facility or converted to electronic and destroyed

provisions.title: Data Destruction
provisions.content: Data must be destroyed securely using certified methods.

subProvisions.title: Destruction Methods
items: Electronic Data: Secure deletion using certified data wiping software
Electronic Data: Destruction of physical media via certified vendor
Paper Records: Shredding via certified vendor
Paper Records: Certificate of destruction obtained

subProvisions.title: Destruction Process
subProvisions.content: Annual review conducted in January each year:
items: IT/Records Manager identifies data/documents eligible for destruction
Legal reviews and confirms no legal holds
Governance Lead approves destruction list
Execute destruction
Document destruction (what, when, by whom)
Retain destruction certificates

provisions.title: Data Privacy Considerations
provisions.content: Balance data privacy rights with legal retention obligations.

subProvisions.title: GDPR / CCPA
subProvisions.content: Participants may request deletion of personal data. Process for deletion requests:
items: Participant submits request to Privacy Contact
Privacy/Legal reviews against retention obligations
If within retention period: Explain legal requirement to retain
If past retention period: Execute deletion and confirm to participant

subProvisions.title: Data Minimization
items: Purge unnecessary personal data even before retention period ends
Anonymize data sets when personal identifiers not needed
Aggregate data for analysis where possible

provisions.title: Roles and Responsibilities
provisions.content: Clearly defined roles for all parties involved in data retention.

tables.caption: Data Retention Roles and Responsibilities
rows: Define retention requirements, manage legal holds, approve destruction
Implement storage systems, execute secure deletion, backup management
Maintain retention schedule, coordinate reviews, approve destruction
Tag data for retention, prepare for archival
Retain financial records per schedule, coordinate with Tax
Follow retention policy, identify records for legal hold

provisions.title: Exceptions and Special Cases
provisions.content: Provisions for permanent retention, shortened retention, and extended retention.

subProvisions.title: Permanent Retention
items: Corporate governance charters
Significant policy documents
Board-approved compensation programs (summary level)

subProvisions.title: Shortened Retention
subProvisions.content: May be destroyed earlier than 7 years (with Legal approval):
items: Duplicate copies (retain one official copy)
Drafts (after final version approved)
Routine communications with no legal significance

subProvisions.title: Extended Retention
items: Required by specific law (e.g., certain securities matters)
Legal hold in effect
Historical significance for company
Approved by Legal for business reasons

provisions.title: Audit and Compliance
provisions.content: Regular audits to ensure compliance with the retention schedule.

subProvisions.title: Internal Audit
items: Compliance with retention schedule
Proper archival of records
Timely destruction of eligible records
Adequacy of backup/recovery procedures
Security of archived data

subProvisions.title: External Audit Support
items: Provide records as requested
Demonstrate retention policy compliance
Show documentation is complete for audit period
Provide destruction logs if requested

provisions.title: Training and Awareness
provisions.content: All employees handling compensation data must understand retention requirements, know how to identify records for legal hold, follow proper procedures for archival and destruction, and report retention policy violations.

federalLaws: IRS retention requirements (minimum 3 years, 7 years recommended)
FLSA (Fair Labor Standards Act) - 3 years certain records
stateLaws: State wage laws (3-7 years depending on state)
